content:
I'm have some math background but I'm not pursuing it. I learned about lean a few weeks ago and I'm trying it out. Some things just don't work for me the way the book says it should. 

example : ∀ m n : Nat, Even n → Even (m * n) := by
  rintro m n ⟨k, hk⟩
  use m * k
  rw [hk]
  ring

This is from the lean documentation Mathematics in lean, overview. When I copy and paste this into vs code, "use" isn't recognized as a tactic. Even worse, "even" isn't recognized. Nat.Even doesn't work either. I got fed up trying different words. The last "ring" isn't recognized either. Did they change the syntax for use? Am I using an old version, is "use" the new method and my compiler doesn't know it?

Do you have anything imported? These tactics are not part of core Lean, and you need to import them in some way.

It looks like https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathematics_in_lean/blob/master/MIL/C01_Introduction/S02_Overview.lean imports import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity and import MIL.Common. The first is probably sufficient to get the tactics.

I can't import anything. import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity says unknown package 'Mathlib' . import MIL.common says unknown package MIL . Is this because I'm on vs code? I've never used that before. I downloaded it because I saw lean was integrated into it. How can I get the compiler to find the package?

VS Code works fine (I use it for Lean). Make sure to follow the instructions for setting up Mathematics in Lean: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathematics_in_lean/C01_Introduction.html#getting-started

That'll give you a particular version of Lean along with Mathlib and the MIL repository. Then, if you want to experiment, you can create your own scratch file inside of the MIL repository, or just edit any of the files that are already there.

I'm still having trouble. Having followed the instructions to clone that book, the code in there works. Then I followed the instructions to "Create" a lean project. `lake +leanprover/lean4:nightly-2024-04-24 new my_project math Was the first thing to do, and math in this is the mathlib it says. I am able to import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity, but ring I believe is comes inside MIL.Common and I'm not able to import that unknown package 'MIL', maybe because I didn't declare that when I created the project? What is the easy way for it to find out when a package isn't available and download it for me, the way miktex does.
I realize now that MIL.Common is including the Common.lean file which contained import Mathlib.Tactic and import Mathlib.Util.Delaborators. Errors are gone, thanks for walking me through it!
